text.0: make glad with songs that ram whom many men invoke worthy of songs of praise indra the sea of wealth.
text.1: whose gracious deeds for men spread like the heavens abroad sing praise to him the sage most liberal for our good.
text.2: as aids the skilful Ṛbhus yearned to indra strong to save who fills midair encompassed round with might.
text.3: rushing in rapture and oer Śatakratu came the gladdening shout that urged him on to victory.
text.4: thou hast disclosed the kines stall for the aṅgirases and made a way for atri by a hundred doors.
text.5: on vimada thou hast bestowed both food and wealth making thy bolt dance in the sacrificers fight.
text.6: thou hast unclosed the prisons of the waters thou hast in the mountain seized the treasure rich in gifts.
text.7: when thou hadst slain with might the dragon vṛtra thou indra didst raise the sun in heaven for all to see.
text.8: with wondrous might thou blewest enchanter fiends away with powers celestial those who called on thee in jest.
text.9: thou herohearted hast broken down piprus forts and helped Ṛjiśvan when the dasyus were struck dead.
text.10: thou savedst kutsa when Śuṣṇa was smitten down to atithigva gavest Śambara for a prey.
text.11: een mighty arbuda thou troddest under foot thou from of old wast born to strike the dasyus dead.
text.12: all power and might is closely gathered up in thee thy bounteous spirit joys in drinking soma juice.
text.13: known is the thunderbolt that lies within thine arms rend off therewith all manly prowess of our foe.
text.14: discern thou well Āryas and dasyus punishing the lawless give them up to him whose grass is strewn.
text.15: be thou the sacrificers strong encourager all these thy deeds are my delight at festivals.
text.16: indra gives up the lawless to the pious man destroying by the strong ones those who have no strength.
text.17: vamra when glorified destroyed the gathered piles of the still waxing great one who would reach the heaven.
text.18: the might which uśanā hath formed for thee with might rends in its greatness and with strength both worlds apart.
text.19: o herosouled the steeds of vāta yoked by thought have carried thee to fame while thou art filled with power.
text.20: when indra hath rejoiced with kāvya uśanā he mounts his steeds who swerve wider and wider yet.
text.21: the strong hath loosed his bolt with the swift rush of rain and he hath rent in pieces Śuṣṇas firmbuilt forts.
text.22: thou mountest on thy car amid strong soma draughts Śāryāta brought thee those in which thou hast delight.
text.23: indra when thou art pleased with men whose soma flows thou risest to unchallenged glory in the sky.
text.24: to old kakṣīvān somapresser skilled in song o indra thou didst give the youthful vṛcayā.
text.25: thou very wise wast menā vrsanśvas child those deeds of thine must all be told at soma feasts.
text.26: the good mans refuge in his need is indra firm as a doorpost praised among the pajras.
text.27: indra alone is lord of wealth the giver lover of riches chariots kine and horses.
text.28: to him the mighty one the selfresplendent verily strong and great this praise is uttered.
text.29: may we and all the heroes with the princes be in this fray o indra in thy keeping.
